history.content:
They might use some Monte Carlo algorithms which have some nice performance guarantees, or just throw a lot of money at it.

This is also a large problem for people who program embedded systems software for aircraft and cars, as they need a lot of provable performance guarantees (prove that this code path won't execute more than 250 times)

------------------

I also don't know anything about solving LPs in practice.

I would expect that if there were LPs that were that large, either you exploit particular properties of the LP, or you just approximate the answer instead of solving exactly.

A quick Google search finds this paper from 2006, which implies that solving an LP of a billion equations was fairly impressive then; I don't immediately see anything newer. In a decade, I imagine that solvers have improved, but I'm not sure by how much.

Of course, sometimes there are particular properties to exploit (for example, if the LP has trillions of equations but only a small constant number of variables, you can use a low dimensionality solver to solve in time that is linear with respect to the number of equations (but factorial with respect to the number of variables)).

They might use some Monte Carlo algorithms which have some nice performance guarantees, or just throw a lot of money at it.

This is also a large problem for people who program embedded systems software for aircraft and cars, as they need a lot of provable performance guarantees (prove that this code path won't execute more than 250 times)

children.subject: Hundreds of trillions isn't more than the number of atoms in the universe... just image a large pile of hundreds of 1TB hard drives.
Thanks Anon. Do you have any examples btw?
No, I don't really know anything about linear programming, sorry :|
Can someone give an example where hundreds of trillions of equations need to be solved. That's more than the number of atoms in the universe.

history.content:
This semester I took cs 170 where I learned linear programming. All the examples we studied were very easy though and could be solved manually. In the real world, though, you have hundreds of billions, and more often, hundreds of trillions, of equations to solve. I saw these problems first hand while interning at Facebook last year before freshman year.

How is lin programming re-implemented at scale?
history.subject: Linear programming with hundreds of billions of equations
